title: 110_s1276
content: The "Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008" clarifies signature capture and retention for electronic methamphetamine precursor logbook systems under the Controlled Substances Act. It ensures that sellers comply with specific requirements when selling products related to methamphetamine production. The "Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008" requires purchasers to present a valid identification card issued by the State or Federal Government and sign a logbook with their name, address, date, and time of sale. For electronic logbooks, purchasers can provide a signature using a designated device. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 mandates purchasers to sign a logbook using a designated electronic device or a bound paper book with a printed sticker displaying their name. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 requires purchasers to sign a logbook with detailed information about the sale, including product name, quantity, purchaser's name and address, date and time of sale, and a unique identifier. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 mandates sellers to provide a document to purchasers containing product details, purchaser information, sale date and time, and a signature line. The signed document must be stored securely after purchase. The seller records product name and quantity sold in a logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook also includes purchaser's name, address, sale date, and time. The seller must verify purchaser information entered in the logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook includes a notice about providing accurate information. The seller must maintain logbook entries for at least 2 years. Providing false information may result in criminal penalties under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code.
